PyCESim package

Submodules

PyCESim.PyCESim module

class PyCESim.PyCESim.CEChannel(charges, p, label='None')[source]

Bases: object

Class for CE channel. For now this refers to a charge distribution, but could be extended to capture different (molecular) fragments etc.

Parameters:

  • charges – array of charges

  • p – probability of this channel occuring in the simulation

class PyCESim.PyCESim.CESim(starting_conditions)[source]

Bases: object

Class for CE simulation results and methods. :param starting_conditions:

make_timebins(t_range_list, n_step_list)[source]

Create timebins for simulation.

Parameters:

  • t_range_list – list of tuples of (t1,t2) between which we will populate timestemps

  • n_step_list – number of timestemps to be populated within each range (t1,t2)

newton_equations(t, y)[source]

Setup Newton equations for ODE solver.

Parameters:

  • t – array of timebins for ODE calculation.

  • y – the first natoms*3 elements are x,y,z positions of each atom.

The next natoms*3 elements are vx,vy,vz of each atom

Returns:

dydt array the first natoms*3 are vx,vy,vz positions of each atom (i.e second half of y).

Next natoms*3 are ax,ay,az (from F=ma)

output_list_to_arr()[source]

Convert simulation output from list of arrays (self.output_list) to a single array (self.output_arr)

output_list_to_df()[source]

Convert simulation output from list of arrays to a Pandas dataframe (stored in self.output_df)

run_sims(n_print=100, save_all=False, make_df=True)[source]

Simulate CE for each starting condition

set_timebins(timebins)[source]

Store timebins and related parameters for simulation.

store_output(solution)[source]

Take solution from ODE solver and convert to output (stored in self.output_list).

class PyCESim.PyCESim.Geometry(atom_coords, atom_masses, element_list=[], atom_nos=array([], dtype=float64), atom_labels=array([], dtype=float64), geom_label=None, nmodes=array([], dtype=float64), omegas=array([], dtype=float64))[source]

Bases: object

Class for (equilibrium) molecular geometry and related information.

Parameters:

  • atom_coords – numpy array of the 3D position of each atom in the structure

  • atom_masses – numpy array of the atomic mass of each atom in the structure

  • element_list – list of element of each atom

  • atom_nos – list of atomic numbers of each atom

  • atom_labels – list of strings used to label each atom

  • geom_label – Optional, additional label used to identify this geometry

  • nmodes – Optional, normal modes

  • omegs – Optional, vibrational frequencies

check_normal_modes(threshold=0.05, make_fig=True)[source]

Check if normal modes are orthogonal and re-weight them correctly (in self.nmodes_weighted). Currently function works for GAMESS format modes, need to expand to other formats.

com_geometry()[source]

Shift geometry to set centre-of-mass to zero. New geometry is stored in self.atom_coods_com

find_com()[source]

Find centre-of-mass of geometry. Stored in self.com

get_elements()[source]

Gets list of elements (stored in self.element_list) from atomic numbers (stored in self.atom_nos)

visualize_2D(dim1=0, dim2=1, markersize=30, markeredgewidth=3)[source]

Visualizes a 2D projection of the molecular structure

Parameters:

  • dim1 – first dimension (0=x, 1=y etc.) of the 2D histogram

  • dim2 – second dimension (0=x, 1=y etc.) of the 2D histogram

  • markersize – size of atom marker (default 30)

  • markeredgewidth – edgewidth of atom marker (default 3)

class PyCESim.PyCESim.StartingConditions(eq_geometry)[source]

Bases: object

Class for generating starting conditions for CE simulation.

Parameters:

eq_geometry – (equilibrium) geometry

generate_pool(n_geoms, method='gaussian', random_rotate=True, sigma=0.1, wigner_sample_max=3, T=0, nmax=5)[source]

Main method for generating the pool of starting conditions for simulation.

Parameters:

  • n_geoms – number of samples in the pool

  • method – [‘gaussian’, ‘wigner’] method of blurring geometries. If ‘gaussian’, geometries are just convolved

by a Gaussian distribution of width sigma. If ‘wigner’, instead sample from vibrational wigner distribution with a specified temeprature. This requires the geometry to include normal modes as appropriate. :param sigma: sigma for Gaussian convolution :param random_rotate: if True, randomly rotate each sampled geometry :param wigner_sample_max: the max (absolute) value of P and Q used for Wigner sampling :param T: temperature for wigner sampling :param nmax: max vibrational state considered for wigner sampling

set_channel_list(channel_list)[source]

Add a list of different channels to the object

Parameters:

channel_list – list of CEChannel objects

sigma_to_array()[source]

Convert sigma from single number to 1 element array if needed.

visualize_pool_2D(dim1=0, dim2=1, vmax=100, nbins=200)[source]

Function for visualizing the 2D pool of geometries as a 2D histogram.

Parameters:

  • dim1 – First dimension (0=x, 1=y etc.) of histogram. Default 0

  • dim2 – Second dimension (0=x, 1=y etc.) of histogram. Default 1

  • vmax – Maximum for colorbar. Default 100

  • nbins – Number of bins in each dimension for 2D histogram. Default 200

wigner_histograms()[source]

Quick plot of histograms of n and Q

PyCESim.PyCESim.calc_Pn(omega_cm, T, n)[source]

Calculate probability of populating vibrational state n.

Parameters:

  • omega_cm – vibrational frequency (in wavenumbers)

  • T – temperature (in K)

  • n – vibrational state

Returns:

P(n, omega,T) - probability of being in state n

PyCESim.PyCESim.calc_W(P, Q, n=0)[source]

Calculate unitless Wigner function.

Parameters:

  • P – unitless momentum

  • Q – unitless position

  • n – vibrational state (0 by default)

Returns:

W(P,Q,n)

PyCESim.PyCESim.calc_canonical_partition(omega, T)[source]

Calculate vibrational canonical partition function.

Parameters:

  • omega – vibrational frequency

  • T – temperature (k)

Returns:

Z(omega,T) - canonical partition function

PyCESim.PyCESim.calc_vib_energy(n, omega)[source]

Calculate vibrational energy for given n and frequency.

Parameters:

  • n – vibrational state

  • omega – vibrational frequency

Returns:

En = hbar * omega * (n+1/2)

PyCESim.PyCESim.coulomb_force(r1, r2, q1, q2)[source]

Calculate Coulomb force between two charges in SI units.

Parameters:

  • r1 – (3D) position of charge 1 (in m)

  • r2 – (3D) position of charge 2 (in m)

  • q1 – charge 1 (in C)

  • q2 – charge 2 (in C)

Returns:

Coulomb force (in N)

PyCESim.PyCESim.rand_rotation_matrix(deflection=1.0, randnums=None)[source]

Creates a random rotation matrix. See http://blog.lostinmyterminal.com/python/2015/05/12/random-rotation-matrix.html and http://www.realtimerendering.com/resources/GraphicsGems/gemsiii/rand_rotation.c

Parameters:

deflection – the magnitude of the rotation. For 0, no rotation; for 1, competely random

rotation. Small deflection => small perturbation. :param randnums: 3 random numbers in the range [0, 1]. If None, they will be auto-generated.

Returns:

random rotation matrix

PyCESim.PyCESim.random_rotation(r_list)[source]

Randomly rotate a list of vectors. See https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/442418/random-generation-of-rotation-matrices

Parameters:

r_list – list of vector arrays.

Returns:

list of ranomdly rotated vector arrays.

PyCESim.PyCESim.read_log(log_file)[source]

Read in a log file. Currently just tested for GAMESS(US)

Parameters:

log_file – ‘.log’ file produced by a quantum chemistry software

Returns:

Geometry object

PyCESim.PyCESim.read_traj_xyz(xyz_file)[source]

(Experimental) Read in a trajectory (.xyz) file

Parameters:

xyz_file – .xyz file containing series of molecular coordinates, representing different timesteps in a trajectory

Returns:

(list of Geometry objects, list of timesteps)

xyz_file – .xyz file containing molecular coordinates
